summary: Reasonable suspicion determination was a mixed question of law and fact supported by the record and therefore beyond further review.
People's appeal dismissed because the Appellate Division reversal was not on the law alone or the law and facts.

Extreme emotional disturbance defense was properly rejected because defendant's offer of proof was insufficient, and the court did not reach the notice question. Felony murder sufficiency claim lacked merit; convictions affirmed.
Compelled photographs of defendant's tattoos were non-testimonial physical characteristics and did not violate the Fifth Amendment.
Victim's complaint qualified as a prompt outcry given the circumstances, and summation objections did not warrant reversal.

Jury unanimity was not required between command and actual-killer theories, and the confession was voluntary with door-opening permitting other-crimes statements. Death sentence was vacated and case remitted for resentencing; judgment otherwise affirmed.
After the first round of jury selection, the court had discretion to seat one prospective juror at a time; the procedure was lawful though inefficient.
Point-blank shooting was a quintessentially intentional attack, making depraved indifference murder legally unsupportable. Appellate Division reversal of the murder conviction was affirmed.
Sentencing courts have discretion to allow more than one victim impact statement, and no abuse occurred here.
A defendant may request a supporting deposition when ticketed, and the 30-day period runs from the request; service 39 days later was untimely. County Court's dismissal was affirmed.
Expert police testimony on drug packaging and quantity was properly admitted to show intent to sell.
Expert testimony about money-handling in multi-member drug operations was improper in a single-transaction case, but the error was harmless.
Defense counsel's testimony against his client at a Sirois hearing created a conflict requiring reversal. New trial ordered.
Under the door-opening doctrine, cross-examination about one identification allowed admission of another otherwise inadmissible identification. No abuse of discretion; order affirmed.
Lineup identifications were not suppressed despite a Payton violation because exclusion was not required under the circumstances.
A parent can invoke a juvenile's right to counsel, but did not do so here.
The meaningful-representation standard applies to ineffective assistance of appellate counsel, and counsel met that standard. Coram nobis denial affirmed.
Permanent orders of protection issued at sentencing are appealable, but defendant's claims were unpreserved; Appellate Division affirmed. The People's appeal was dismissed for lack of jurisdiction.
The court's supplemental instruction to a deadlocked jury was coercive and unbalanced. Appellate Division's reversal was affirmed.
During execution of arrest warrants, a limited security inquiry of defendant was reasonable, and suppression was properly denied.
Defendant's dissatisfaction and strategic disagreements with assigned counsel did not require substitution.
A grand jury must formally vote with 12 jurors to dismiss a charge; a failure to indict is not a dismissal. Indictment reinstated; order affirmed.
Single eyewitness identification was not incredible as a matter of law and sufficed to support the conviction.
Arrest at the doorway or after defendant exited his home did not violate Payton, and the codefendant statement was admitted for state of mind, not truth.
Signing one's own name to a corporate check without authority is not forgery; authority and authenticity are distinct. Conviction reversed and indictment dismissed.
Alleged defects in the issuance of an order of protection were nonjurisdictional and forfeited by a guilty plea. Conviction affirmed.
The death-penalty deadlock instruction rendered the statute unconstitutional, requiring vacatur of the death sentence and remittal for noncapital sentencing. Convictions were otherwise affirmed.
Officer reasonably detained a taxi passenger to verify suspected fare evasion.
The record as a whole showed a knowing, voluntary and intelligent waiver of counsel.
The sentencing court conducted a sufficient inquiry into violation of the plea agreement, and defendant admitted the violations.
A point-blank shooting was intentional, making depraved indifference murder legally insufficient. Order reversed and indictment dismissed.
Defendant's refusal to permit counsel to participate did not bar the court from proceeding; no Sixth Amendment violation occurred.
A licensed physician may be prosecuted for aiding and abetting unlicensed practice of medicine; evidence and jury-note response were sufficient.
Arthur rule did not apply because the interrogating police were not informed of representation. Statements were admissible; order affirmed.
Evidence suggesting defendant possessed a stolen car (a charge dismissed by the grand jury) was unfairly prejudicial and not harmless. New trial ordered.
Anonymous undercover testimony was admitted without the required Stanard showing, violating confrontation rights. Conviction reversed and new trial ordered.
Admission of the alibi notice was error where the defense presented a new, unnoticed alibi, but the error was harmless given overwhelming evidence.
Defendant's signature on an order of protection adequately alleged knowledge for a criminal contempt information. Appellate Term reversed; case remitted.
Multiple homicides committed in a continuous course of conduct constituted the same criminal transaction for first-degree murder. Conviction affirmed.
Upon resentencing after a mistaken predicate-felon adjudication, the People may allege a different predicate, but cannot withdraw consent to the plea if predicate status fails.
Sidebar during defendant's testimony concerned a legal issue and was not a Sandoval or Ventimiglia hearing; no right-to-be-present violation.
Judicial-bias claim was unpreserved, and counsel was not ineffective regarding corroboration of defendant's confession.
The castle-doctrine exception to the duty to retreat applies even when assailant and defender share the dwelling.
Record was insufficient to decide diligence under Parris for missing minutes; case remitted to determine diligence and whether a reconstruction hearing is required. Order reversed and remitted.
Loss of minutes did not warrant reversal; reconstruction hearings were denied absent reasonable diligence or, after a guilty plea, identification of appealable issues.
